author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Australian Military Moves to Dismiss Soldiers After Killings in Afghanistan
description: A scathing report revealed that members of the special forces had waged a campaign to cover up unlawful killings of Afghan civilians.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — One week after the release of a damning report that revealed Australian special forces had unlawfully killed helpless Afghan civilians and waged a campaign to cover up the slaughter, the military has begun proceedings to dismiss 13 soldiers serving in the force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nathaniel Popper
title: ‘Tokenized’: Inside Black Workers’ Struggles at the King of Crypto Start-Ups
description: Coinbase, the most valuable U.S. cryptocurrency company, has faced many internal complaints about discriminatory treatment.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — One by one, they left. Some quit. Others were fired. All were Black.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deborah Solomon
title: Did John McCracken Make That Monolith in Utah?
description: It is a riddle, wrapped in a mystery, buried in the desert: His dealer says yes. His son says maybe. His artist buddies, like Ed Ruscha, say, no way the sculptor created this tall, silvery object.
content: At first it sounded like a plot twist from a science-fiction novel by Philip K. Dick. A tall, silvery slice of metal, about 10 feet high with an aura of strangeness about it, is spotted in the red-rock canyons of the Utah desert. State employees who found it while surveying the land for bighorn sheep say they have no idea who drove the slab of metal into the rock floor. And in the days since, the riddle of what it is and how it got there has proved irresistible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: Behind the Scenes, Romance Catches a Spark
description: Devin Keudell and Matt Polk, who are both in the theater industry, finally made a connection while working on “Rocky the Musical.”
content: Matt Polk got his first glimpse of Devin Keudell one day in the early 2000s, when Mr. Keudell was standing in a doorway at the Broadway League’s Spring Road Conference, an annual industry conference for theater on Broadway and across the country held at a hotel in Midtown Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Wilkinson
title: Why Did So Many Americans Vote for Trump?
description: To the dismay of Democrats, the president’s strategy of ignoring the pandemic mostly worked for Republicans.
content: President Trump’s disastrous mishandling of the coronavirus pandemic probably cost him re-election. Yet it seems mind-boggling that he still won more votes than any incumbent president in American history despite his dereliction of responsibility at a time of a once-in-a-century health crisis and economic devastation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: India’s Economy Shrinks Sharply as Covid-19 Slams Small Businesses
description: The latest data firmly establishes India’s position among the worst-performing major economies, despite government spending meant to blunt the pandemic’s impact.
content: NEW DELHI — China has come roaring back from the devastation of Covid-19, and the United States, Europe and Japan are finding their feet. But the hundreds of millions of laborers and shopkeepers who keep India’s economy running still can’t find relief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton and Samantha Hahn
title: Paul Smith on How to Sew Patches in a Traditional Japanese Stitch
description: In the latest installment of our Designer D.I.Y. series, learn how to breathe new life into old clothes with a classic sashiko stitch.
content: What to do with a beloved jacket in which the elbows have gone or a shirt with frayed cuffs? The British designer Sir Paul Smith, known for his sharp suits and signature rainbow stripes and who is celebrating 50 years in fashion, thinks you should look to a sartorial solution passed down through multiple generations of Japanese laborers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: It’s 2020, So of Course Mike Tyson Is Boxing Again
description: The return offers started coming when videos of Tyson sparring at age 54 gained steam online. They landed on a bout with Roy Jones Jr., another champion from long ago.
content: Mike Tyson is back for a pay-per-view fight. Well, not exactly a fight. (“It’s an exhibition bout between two former champions,” said a seemingly exasperated Andy Foster, the California State Athletic Commission executive officer. “I don’t know another way to put it.”)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: All That We Have Lost
description: Part of Diego Maradona’s enduring appeal is testament to his genius. But part of it, too, speaks to a sense of nostalgia for what he represented.
content: There was a commotion over in the corner of the Krestovsky Stadium in St. Petersburg. A whole section of fans seemed to have turned its eyes away from the field and trained them instead on a glass-fronted suite. They stood on their seats and craned their necks and peered over shoulders to try to get a better view.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Sokol
title: Art Basel Miami Beach Was Canceled, but the Show Goes On
description: As coronavirus deaths rose, museums and galleries have rolled out new shows. The socialite Libbie Mugrabi is planning a dinner for the ages. Is Miami’s art world clueless?
content: Call it the zombie version of Art Basel Miami Beach. The annual fair, originally scheduled to unfold next week with the contemporary art world converging in South Florida, was canceled in September by its Swiss-based organizers — a cultural casualty of the coronavirus. Over a dozen Miami satellite fairs followed suit, all mirroring Basel’s pivot to online “viewing rooms.” The art circus, it seemed, was not coming to town.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: I Don’t Want to Be the Office Grandma
description: Advice for getting back into the work force at 60, dealing with shame and co-workers, and how to cope with losing all motivation for working from home.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, even if you want them withheld. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sullivan
title: Groups Trying to Open Golf to Young People Are Struggling Themselves
description: Even as more young men and women in need want to play, the pandemic has made it more difficult for nonprofits to raise money.
content: Golf has been having a boom year since courses that were closed in the pandemic reopened in June.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: In Harsh Rebuke, Appeals Court Rejects Trump’s Election Challenge in Pennsylvania
description: “Voters, not lawyers, choose the president,” a judge for the Third Circuit Court of Appeals wrote in the 21-page repudiation of Mr. Trump’s legal effort to halt Pennsylvania’s certification process.
content: In a blistering decision, a Philadelphia appeals court ruled on Friday that the Trump campaign could not stop — or attempt to reverse — the certification of the voting results in Pennsylvania, reprimanding the president’s team by noting that “calling an election unfair does not make it so.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: A Black Friday Like no Other
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: It’s Black Friday, the typical start of the holiday shopping season. But as with so many other things, this year’s version will not look like it usually does.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson and Jack Ewing
title: Brexit Is Nipping at London’s Role as a Financial Powerhouse
description: Britain and the European Union don’t trust each other much, and global banks are caught in the middle.
content: LONDON — For Britain, its exit from the European Union is supposed to be the start of a new era as a “Global Britain,” an open, inviting and far-reaching country. For the European Union, Brexit is an opportunity to repatriate some business from across the English Channel and further bolster the continent’s economic standing in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Empowered by an Odds-Defying Win, Susan Collins Is Ready to Deal
description: The senator from Maine has emerged from the toughest re-election battle of her career more influential than ever, and ready to play a crucial deal-making role in a divided Senate.
content: WASHINGTON — The calls began pouring in even before Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, bounded onto a makeshift stage in a snowy parking lot in Bangor to declare victory in a race she was supposed to have lost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: Britain Set to Leap Ahead in Approving Vaccines
description: Regulators may approve the troubled AstraZeneca vaccine and the American-made Pfizer shot weeks before the U.S. does so.
content: LONDON — Britain asked its drug regulator on Friday to consider AstraZeneca’s coronavirus vaccine for emergency approval, forging ahead in the face of considerable uncertainty about the vaccine’s effectiveness as the government tries to corral a pandemic that has killed more than 66,000 people in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Pentagon Chief Visits Somalia Ahead of Expected Troop Cuts
description: Acting Defense Secretary Christopher C. Miller met with troops and commanders in the region as turmoil bedevils the nation with approaching elections and an enduring threat from the Shabab.
content: WASHINGTON — Acting Defense Secretary Christopher C. Miller met with American troops and diplomats in Somalia on Friday, the first Pentagon chief to visit the strife-torn East African nation. He may also be the last.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: As Qaeda Terrorist Leaves Prison, Victims’ Families Relive the Pain
description: The release of Adel Abdel Bary, 60, after 21 years of incarceration has left relatives of some bombing victims uneasy.
content: Edith Bartley knew the day would come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Rothkopf
title: Some Movies Actually Understand Poverty in America
description: The complex realities of subsistence escape “Hillbilly Elegy.” But as far back as Charlie Chaplin’s “City Lights,” filmmakers have been turning a discerning eye on destitution.
content: There’s a scene in Ron Howard’s new “Hillbilly Elegy” that approaches the quiet dignity I wish the rest of the movie had. Glenn Close stands in a doorway. She’s playing Mamaw, the proud Appalachian grandmother of the high schooler who will eventually write the memoir on which the film is based. Mamaw accepts a free dinner from Meals on Wheels. And while it pains her to do so, she asks for more food. The delivery kid blinks, embarrassed. But he bends the rules a little and the two connect over a small but meaningful act of charity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Six U.S. Oil Executives Are Convicted of Corruption in Venezuela
description: The so-called Citgo 6, who had been lured to Venezuela three years ago for a business meeting, were immediately sentenced to prison.
content: CARACAS, Venezuela — A Venezuelan judge on Thursday found six American oil executives guilty of a wide-ranging corruption scheme and immediately sentenced them to prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: Clicking Back Into Each Other’s Lives
description: Maxwell Sugerman and Maria Lopez, who met on a dating app in 2017, postponed their wedding five times before saying “I do.”
content: Maxwell Sugerman treasures Maria Lopez, whom he met after investing $4 on a dating app, Coffee Meets Bagel, in August 2017.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Weed
title: Job Interviews Without Interviewers, Products of the Pandemic
description: Video responses to set questions, online games that measure a person’s traits and skills: The future of interviews is coming to a wider variety of professions in the pandemic.
content: So much of our work lives has moved online during the pandemic: group meetings, chats with the boss — even interviewing for a new job. The pandemic has also led companies to conduct “interviews” without an interviewer. Job applicants are being asked to video record answers to set questions about their experience, skills and personal qualities, rather than speaking with a recruiter by phone or video chat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel L. Harris and Lisa Tarchak
title: ‘Democracy Should Not Be Taken for Granted’
description: Readers around the world tell us about the global ripple effect of the U.S. election.
content: “Mr. Biden has vowed to turn the page on the ‘aberration’ of Mr. Trump’s foreign policy,” wrote Robert Malley and Philip H. Gordon in the Op-Ed “Trump Still Has 70 Days to Wreak Havoc Around the World.” But is that what people around the world really want?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Walt Bogdanich and Michael Forsythe
title: McKinsey Proposed Paying Pharmacy Companies Rebates for OxyContin Overdoses
description: Court filings reveal consultants’ talk of a records purge during the opioid crisis, and shed new light on sales advice given to the billionaire Sackler family and their drug company, Purdue Pharma.
content: When Purdue Pharma agreed last month to plead guilty to criminal charges involving OxyContin, the Justice Department noted the role an unidentified consulting company had played in driving sales of the addictive painkiller even as public outrage grew over widespread overdoses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: Her Antenna Is Tuned to the Quietest Voices
description: Yu Miri won a National Book Award for “Tokyo Ueno Station,” a novel whose main character is the ghost of a homeless construction worker.
content: TOKYO — Walking on an autumn Saturday through Ueno Park, one of this city’s most popular attractions, the novelist Yu Miri was stunned by how beautified the grounds seemed since her last visit several years earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: The Exquisite Angst of Applying to College in a Deeply Anxious Year
description: The pandemic has changed everything about the stressful admissions process, adding even more strain on students.
content: As a new season for college applications begins, the coronavirus has upended the process, forcing millions of students to learn remotely, canceling college tours and standardized testing dates, and preventing legions of students from participating in sports and other extracurricular activities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi, David E. Sanger, Eric Schmitt and Ronen Bergman
title: Iran’s Top Nuclear Scientist Killed in Ambush, State Media Say
description: U.S. and Israeli intelligence described the scientist, Mohsen Fakhrizadeh, as the force behind what they call Iran’s covert push for nuclear weapons.
content: This briefing has ended. Check here for further details.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: The Unexpected Message Revealed by Long Lines for Virus Testing
description: All over New York City, thousands spent hours waiting at clinics, motivated by a deep need to visit their parents.
content: Volumes have been written about the ways the culture of parenthood has changed over the past half-century — about the deep connection and mutual dependence forged between nascent adults and the people who raised them, devoted wardens and their ordained. Rarely do we get a physical image that makes the shift so apparent. Covid, strangely, has given this to us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Ken Belson
title: The Baltimore Ravens’ star quarterback is said to have tested positive for the virus.
description: Lamar Jackson, the Baltimore Ravens quarterback and the National Football League’s reigning Most Valuable Player, on Thursday became the highest-profile player to test positive for the coronavirus as an outbreak of cases spread to more than a dozen players on the team, according to several media outlets.
content: Lamar Jackson, the Baltimore Ravens quarterback and the National Football League’s reigning Most Valuable Player, on Thursday became the highest-profile player to test positive for the coronavirus as an outbreak of cases spread to more than a dozen players on the team, according to several media outlets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: ‘Mr. Downstairs’ Had the Key to Her Heart
description: Elma Holder and Jerry Stallings met at a retirement community in Yukon, Okla. His apartment was directly under hers, one flight below.
content: Elma Holder couldn’t help feeling ridiculous on days when “Jerry Downstairs,” as she called him, would leave the retirement community building they lived in to visit his lady friend in town.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson
title: Covid Overload: U.S. Hospitals Are Running Out of Beds for Patients
description: As the coronavirus pandemic surges across the country, hospitals are facing a crisis-level shortage of beds and staff to provide adequate care for patients.
content: In excruciating pain with lesions on her face and scalp, Tracey Fine lay for 13 hours on a gurney in an emergency room hallway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz and Isayen Herrera
title: A Mother, Her Son — and Their 1,500-Mile Search for Home
description: Millions of people have been displaced by the pandemic. Jessika and her 6-year-old, Sebastián, are among the many who have yet to find a home.
content: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — A little boy charges along the highway, his red plastic shoes glowing in the twilight. The suitcase he pulls weighs almost as much as he does. A truck throttles by, threatening to blow him off his feet. But Sebastián Ventura, who at just 6 has already taken on the role of family cheerleader, urges his family on.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Pictures of a Thanksgiving That No One Pictured
description: To retain the essence of the holiday in a pandemic-scarred year, many Americans found themselves having to bend Thanksgiving traditions into unexpected shapes.
content: Whether they carved turkeys at outdoor picnic tables, connected with family through video calls or ate stuffing in the break room of a hospital coronavirus ward, many Americans found themselves marking this Thanksgiving in ways they hardly could have foreseen a year ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca J. Ritzel
title: A Second Sudden Exit for a Hard-Charging Artistic Director
description: Ari Roth founded Mosaic Theater Company after being fired by Theater J. He resigned under pressure after complaints from staff.
content: WASHINGTON — After Ari Roth was fired six years ago by the Jewish theater he led here, where he had staged plays raising challenging questions about Israel, some of the nation’s leading directors and dramatists rallied to his defense — even as officials at the theater insisted that his dismissal had nothing to do with politics.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: ‘Love Letter to Detroit,’ on Vellum and Chrome
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, November 27, 2020.
content: “So often the art was hiding in plain sight, within 20 miles of the museum. I was knocking on doors in suburban Detroit, and the sketches were coming out of dusty boxes.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Classic British Rock Group
description: Robyn Weintraub offers us a marvelous way to work off our holiday meals.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Tell me, my friends, is there a better way to celebrate the holiday weekend than with a Robyn Weintraub puzzle? At the very least, the tug of war you will encounter herein has to be good for working off your Thanksgiving meal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Reyburn
title: Sotheby’s and Christie’s Look to Luxury as a Coronavirus Antidote
description: The world’s two biggest auction houses are selling more watches, jewelry and handbags, but art’s still where the money is.
content: LONDON — Twenty‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago, ‌Sotheby’s‌ ‌and‌ ‌Christie’s made money by auctioning‌ ‌art. ‌And‌ ‌that‌ ‌was‌ ‌about‌ ‌it. ‌Now, ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌process‌ ‌fast-forwarded‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌coronavirus pandemic, ‌technology‌ ‌is‌ ‌transforming‌ ‌these‌ ‌venerable‌ ‌names‌ ‌into‌ ‌very‌ ‌different-looking‌ businesses. ‌Luxury‌ ‌is‌ ‌making that ‌difference. ‌ ‌
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Nov. 27, 2020
description: No corrections appeared in print on Friday, Nov. 27, 2020.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Friday, Nov. 27, 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Iranian Diplomat Accused of Plotting to Bomb Dissidents Goes on Trial in Belgium
description: Prosecutors say the diplomat, Assadollah Assadi, was carrying out a plan organized by Iran’s intelligence services against an overseas opposition group.
content: BRUSSELS — The bomb was handed over at a Pizza Hut in Luxembourg. The intent, prosecutors say, was to blow up a rally in France of a prominent opposition group to the Iranian government.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Poem of Gratitude from Oklahoma
description: The New York Times asked poets laureate from across the country what the people in their states had to be thankful for in this difficult year.
content: We are thankful for okla-humma, for our people, for this land.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Gorman and Carl Zimmer
title: The Virus Won’t Stop Evolving When the Vaccine Arrives
description: The coronavirus is not a shape shifter like the flu virus, but it could become vaccine resistant over time. That prompts researchers to urge vigilance.
content: In a 1988 essay on pandemics Joshua Lederberg, Nobel laureate and president of The Rockefeller University, reminded the medical community that when it comes to infectious disease, the laws of Darwin are as important as the vaccines of Pasteur.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zoë Beery
title: The Rich Kids Who Want to Tear Down Capitalism
description: Socialist-minded millennial heirs are trying to live their values by getting rid of their money.
content: Lately, Sam Jacobs has been having a lot of conversations with his family’s lawyers. He’s trying to gain access to more of his $30 million trust fund. At 25, he’s hit the age when many heirs can blow their money on harebrained businesses or a stable of sports cars. He doesn’t want to do that, but by wealth management standards, his plan is just as bad. He wants to give it all away.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Love Letter: Craving Comfort and Connection
description: And how to do a solo holiday season.
content: Since the onset of Covid-19, many people have found themselves feeling nostalgic for more certain times. For C Pam Zhang, the writer of this week’s Modern Love essay, her quick cure for heartache, grief and the isolation of the pandemic is the simple pleasure of her favorite childhood treat — crispy, golden chicken nuggets. The calming properties of processed chicken have brought her both comfort and a deeper connection to her father, who died eight years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Trump, Still Claiming Victory, Says He Will Leave if Electors Choose Biden
description: Taking questions from reporters for the first time since Election Day, the president also said he would travel to Georgia to support Republican candidates before two runoffs that will determine control of the Senate.
content: President Trump said on Thursday that he would leave the White House if the Electoral College formalized Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s election as president, even as he reiterated baseless claims of fraud that he said would make it “very hard” to concede.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: How a Brooklyn Sisterhood of Black Women Became National Power Brokers
description: Ten years ago, the Olori Sisterhood was a small-time “political sorority.” Now they’re ready for a seat at the table.
content: Last November, when Democratic presidential candidates were still jockeying for the nomination, before the coronavirus pandemic killed more than 250,000 Americans and fervent protests against police brutality swept the nation, Senator Kamala Harris of California appeared before a group of mostly Black women in South Carolina to file officially for the state’s critical primary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: England, Covid-19, Tigray: Your Friday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Talking About the 10 Best Books of 2020
description: On a special episode of the podcast, taped live, editors from The New York Times Book Review discuss this year’s outstanding fiction and nonfiction.
content: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: ‘The Mandalorian’ Season 2, Episode 5 Recap: Baby Yoda Has a Name
description: Mando gets a new task from a complicated ally. Baby Yoda gets a back story.
content: Baby Yoda has a name!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: England’s lockdown will lift next week, but many pubs will stay closed.
description: Under fire from critics over the economic and social cost of his coronavirus restrictions, Prime Minister Boris Johnson will bring a grueling, second, national lockdown in England to an end next week.
content: Under fire from critics over the economic and social cost of his coronavirus restrictions, Prime Minister Boris Johnson will bring a grueling, second, national lockdown in England to an end next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Wolfe, Mitch Smith and Lisa Waananen Jones
title: U.S. coronavirus infections shoot past 13 million as officials plead with Americans to spend Black Friday online.
description: The number of coronavirus infections in the United States shot past 13 million on Friday, worsening the world’s largest outbreak. The milestone came as Americans embarked on a Black Friday that looked different from holidays past.
content: The number of coronavirus infections in the United States shot past 13 million on Friday, worsening the world’s largest outbreak. The milestone came as Americans embarked on a Black Friday that looked different from holidays past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Astor
title: Debra White Plume, Defender of Her Tribe, Is Dead at 66
description: She championed the rights of the Oglala Lakota in South Dakota and was a leader in protests at Wounded Knee and oil pipeline sites.
content: Debra White Plume, a prominent Native American activist who faced down police bullets, uranium mining companies and oil pipeline projects in trying to protect the traditional Oglala Lakota way of life, died on Nov. 10 in Rapid City, S.D. She was 66.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Bruce Boynton, Plaintiff in Landmark Civil Rights Case, Dies at 83
description: He was a Black man who wanted to sit in the white section of a bus terminal restaurant. The case reached the Supreme Court.
content: “All he wanted was a cheeseburger,” Judge Myron Thompson of United States District Court in Alabama said at an event two years ago honoring Bruce C. Boynton, “and he changed the course of history.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Apuzzo, Noah Weiland and Selam Gebrekidan
title: Trump Gave W.H.O. a List of Demands. Hours Later, He Walked Away.
description: When President Trump quit the health organization, he left a list of seven demands on the table. Here they are.
content: GENEVA — In late May, the American ambassador in Geneva, Andrew Bremberg, went on a rescue mission to the World Health Organization headquarters. He told its director general, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, that despite weeks of threats that President Trump would quit the health organization, the relationship could still be salvaged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Daniels
title: ‘Black Beauty’ Review: A Melodrama in Need of Rougher Edges
description: Set in the present day, this adaptation of the classic children’s novel forgets why the story of a horse surviving the maliciousness of humans has endured for so long.
content: Written in 1877, Anna Sewell’s classic children’s novel “Black Beauty” warned against the abuse of horses. The pristine adaptation streaming on Disney+ is a melodrama in need of rougher edges. Directed by Ashley Avis (a former competitive equestrian), the movie is set in the present-day United States and features two female protagonists: the fiery mustang Black Beauty (voiced by Kate Winslet) and the recently orphaned Jo (Mackenzie Foy), now living with her uncle John (Iain Glen), training horses at Birtwick Stables.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noele Illien
title: Swiss to Vote on Tougher Responsibility Proposal for Companies
description: A referendum on Sunday, if approved, would make Swiss companies liable for human rights violations and environmental damage by their subsidiaries abroad.
content: For several months, orange flags printed with “Yes!” have hung from balconies across Switzerland, encouraging the public to vote Sunday in favor of an initiative to make Swiss companies liable for human rights violations and environmental damage committed by their subsidiaries abroad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: He Stopped by Her Table, and Then Into Her Life
description: Bamba Sama left a lasting impression on Khrehaan Ebah, who was having lunch two years ago at a TGI Fridays, where Mr. Sama was the general manager.
content: Khrehaan Ebah’s chat with the restaurant manager who asked if she had enjoyed her lunch in March 2018 wasn’t for the benefit of her niece and dining companion, Yaheemah Ebah. But she used it to make a point about the importance of being cordial anyway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Harris
title: In Their 20s and Saving for Retirement: How It Started, How It’s Going
description: Three savers learned some important lessons early on.
content: When Dray Farley was 15, he watched a video his favorite gamer had posted on YouTube. But it wasn’t about Call of Duty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Goodman and Karen Schwartz
title: It’s the Winter of Backcountry. Here’s How to Start Safely.
description: The pandemic has many people wanting to avoid crowded slopes. Going into the backcountry requires avalanche knowledge or a guide. Here are suggestions for taking part across the United States.
content: Backcountry skiing and snowboarding have exploded into the mainstream this year. As ski resorts are limiting access because of the coronavirus pandemic, skiers are looking for alternative ways to recreate while staying physically distanced.  The backcountry boom is also being driven by a new generation of Alpine touring skis and snowboards that make it easier for newcomers to transition from skiing and riding at resorts to the backcountry. REI reports that sales of backcountry ski equipment have tripled since last fall (you can rent it too).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: How Did the North Korean Defector Cross the Border? Loose Screws
description: South Korea said its sensors had malfunctioned, allowing a North Korean to defect undetected, in the military’s most embarrassing border security breach in years.
content: SEOUL, South Korea — It’s the most heavily fortified border in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: Marty McFly and Beer Were the First Pairing That Day
description: Dyanna Quizon and Dane Volek were brought together by a ‘Back to the Future Day’ party. But their bond was cemented through Jane Austen.
content: Dyanna Villaluna Quizon prepared for her first date with Dane Clifford Volek the way most 31-year-olds in 2015 would: She looked him up on the internet. The trouble was, she couldn’t really find anything.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alison Stine
title: Can Cannabis Farms Weather Wildfire Season?
description: Many marijuana crops are uninsured, which means that in the wake of disaster, farmers can face financial ruin.
content: In 2013, Joy Hollingsworth moved with her family from Seattle out to the country with a plan to build a cannabis business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Franklin
title: How Will Co-living Survive the Pandemic?
description: The coronavirus drove vacancies up in co-living buildings, but companies are offering rent deals and flexible leases to bring demand back.
content: The core benefits of co-living took a big hit when the coronavirus struck New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin, Claire Moses and Sarah Hughes
title: Coronavirus Hospitalizations, Iran, Black Friday: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaux Laskey
title: The Coziest White Bean Stew
description: Thousands of readers can’t be wrong about Colu Henry’s roasted tomato and white bean stew.
content: Hello and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes. Margaux here, filling in for Emily this week. I hope you had a lovely Thanksgiving, whatever that looked like for you this year. Mine was small and different, but kind of perfect? It’s been a challenging several months in so many ways, and yet I’ve also never felt so thankful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: In ‘Your Honor,’ a New Orleans Judge Breaks Bad
description: It was the best show idea the writer Peter Moffat had ever heard. Bryan Cranston loved it, too. Their new mini-series asks: How far would you go to protect your child?
content: “It’s the best premise anybody has ever said to me,” Peter Moffat said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives, Tiffany May and Makiko Inoue
title: They Beat Back the Virus (Again and Again and Again)
description: Hard-to-trace clusters, along with pandemic fatigue, have forced officials in Hong Kong, South Korea and Japan to keep recalibrating their responses.
content: HONG KONG — First, it was travelers and university students bringing the coronavirus back to Hong Kong from Europe and the United States. Then, sea crews and bar patrons were the ones spreading infections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: This Year’s Black Friday Designer Fashion Sales May Not Be What You Think.
description: A group of brands and retailers have been trying to reset expectations.
content: Fashion designers and luxury retailers have always had a complicated relationship with Black Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Poletto
title: Welcome to Homeownership
description: New Yorkers who left the city and bought country homes during the pandemic are discovering there’s a lot to learn (and spend) while taking care of a house.
content: Joe DeVito, like many other New Yorkers who wanted more space to weather the pandemic, headed north and bought a two-bedroom house in the Catskills in late July.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C Pam Zhang
title: Junk Food Was Our Love Language
description: To feel close to my father, a man I never fully knew, I eat chicken nuggets.
content: It’s autumn again, the eighth since my father died, and I’m craving chicken nuggets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Makiko Inoue and Ben Dooley
title: A Job for Life, or Not? A Class Divide Deepens in Japan
description: Two court rulings threaten to further entrench distinctions in Japan between “regular” workers and the growing ranks of nonregular employees, many of whom are women.
content: TOKYO — For more than a decade, Setsuko Hikita spent her working days selling snacks and newspapers in the bowels of Tokyo’s bustling metro system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier, Melissa Eddy and Emma Bubola
title: A Chilling Question Divides Europe: Open Ski Slopes or Keep Them Closed?
description: Leading up to the Christmas season, France, Germany and Italy will keep slopes shut, but Austria and Switzerland have vowed to reopen theirs, in Europe’s latest struggle to coordinate a pandemic response.
content: Weeks before the coronavirus pandemic swept across Europe in February, some of the first virus clusters on the continent appeared in ski resorts in the Alps, leading to cascading outbreaks as ski enthusiasts returned home.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Marching to the Beat of Their Own Drum
description: Inspired by this year’s protests against racial injustice, this Derek Fordjour painting reimagines the stars and stripes of the American flag.
content: In each installment of The Artists, T highlights a recent or little-shown work by a Black artist, along with a few words from that artist putting the work in context. This week, we’re looking at a painting by Derek Fordjour, whose solo show at the Petzel Gallery, “Self Must Die,” is on view through Dec. 19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Amazon Wants to Get Even Closer. Skintight.
description: In the pursuit of surveillance as a service, Jeff Bezos is intent on recording even our moods. How much personal data is too much to give to Amazon?
content: Here’s a tip: Don’t get into a car with your family and tell everyone that Jeff Bezos is listening through the device on your wrist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: Biden’s Plan for Seniors Is Not Just a Plan for Seniors
description: The incoming administration aims to tackle child care, elder care, preschool and more in one ambitious aid program.
content: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. has no shortage of ideas about how to transform caregiving. One striking feature of his team’s plan: It does not address elder care separately from child care, or divide plans to support family caregivers from those for paid caregivers. Rather, it takes on Medicaid benefits for older and disabled adults, preschool for toddlers and better jobs for home care workers, all in one ambitious, $775 billion-over-a-decade package.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: As Winter Arrives, Heaters Become a Survival Tool for Businesses
description: A rise in demand for heating equipment has left some products back-ordered for months, possibly jeopardizing prospects for some businesses of getting through the pandemic intact.
content: The must-have accessory for many businesses this winter is basic, but lately it has been hard to find: the humble space heater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: Pushed by Pandemic, Amazon Goes on a Hiring Spree Without Equal
description: The company has added 427,300 employees in 10 months, bringing its global work force to more than 1.2 million.
content: SEATTLE — Amazon has embarked on an extraordinary hiring binge this year, vacuuming up an average of 1,400 new workers a day and solidifying its power as online shopping becomes more entrenched in the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Leszkiewicz
title: How ‘The Crown’ Embraced ’80s Pop
description: Season 4 of the Netflix show takes viewers into a new decade, with a musical soundtrack to match, including artists like Stevie Nicks, Elton John and David Bowie.
content: LONDON — The fourth season of “The Crown” enters a new cultural era: the 1980s. As the plot moves into the Margaret Thatcher years, and a younger generation of royals — including Prince Charles and Diana, Princess of Wales — comes to the forefront of the show, the creator Peter Morgan was eager to take the soundtrack in a new direction, too: pop music from the period. “Naturally, I was over the moon about it,” Sarah Bridge, the music supervisor on the third and fourth seasons, said in a telephone interview. “Stepping into the ’80s was a really exciting time. What an incredible decade of music to choose from.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Put your Thanksgiving leftovers to work, in touriéres, in a sandwich, in soup, or in a panzanella.
content: Good morning. So how’d that go? Weird, right? Not unpleasant, I hope, plenty delicious and fun. But strange indeed to have years of tradition upended by the need to stay safe amid a pandemic, for sure. And boy howdy the leftovers. I wanted to cook a smaller bird. But I ended up with a 17-pounder and, well, I’ve got a lot of cooked turkey meat just now. It’s time, this weekend, to do something about that. You may be in a similar position.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denise Hruby
title: He Once Trafficked in Rare Birds. Now, He Tells How It’s Done.
description: After a chance encounter in Brazil, Johann Zillinger became one of the world’s most prolific wildlife smugglers. Three decades and two prison stints later, he says he has gone straight.
content: WEIDEN AN DER MARCH, Austria — On a humid evening at the airport in Fortaleza, in northern Brazil, Johann Zillinger, a wildlife trafficker, was keeping a close eye on his new hire. He had recruited the 24-year-old farmhand as a smuggler a few days earlier, promising him a free trip to Europe and $2,000 in cash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Ken Belson
title: Ravens Game Against Steelers Is Moved Again, to Tuesday Night
description: Lamar Jackson, the N.F.L.’s 2019 M.V.P., was among more than a dozen Baltimore players to have reportedly tested positive for the virus.
content: For the second time this week, the N.F.L. has rescheduled the matchup between the Pittsburgh Steelers and the Baltimore Ravens, moving it to Tuesday night from Sunday, after the coronavirus outbreak in the Ravens’ clubhouse spread further on Thursday, the original day of the game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Escaping the Virus, Almost
description: How a planned two-week trip to Sydney from Melbourne stretched into a five-month drive across Australia dictated by lockdowns and coronavirus restrictions.
content: In early July, I drove to Sydney from Melbourne for what I had planned as a two-week holiday on Australia’s east coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Cumming-Bruce
title: U.N. Panel: Technology in Policing Can Reinforce Racial Bias
description: The use of artificial intelligence and facial recognition programs may lead communities to lose trust in law enforcement, human rights experts say.
content: GENEVA — Police departments across the United States have been drawn to the use of digital technology for surveillance and predicting crime on the theory that it will make law enforcement more accurate, efficient and effective. The alarming reality, United Nations human rights experts warned on Thursday, is that they risk reinforcing racial bias and abuse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: How Toronto Plans to Keep Schools Open Amid Its Second Lockdown
description: Ontario’s education minister announced a program to test schools’ asymptomatic students and staff in four of the province’s hardest-hit areas, something critics have been demanding for months.
content: TORONTO — On Monday, as I was writing a news article about Canada’s enthusiasm for keeping schools open during the second wave of the coronavirus, an email arrived from my daughter’s high school alerting me that a student had tested positive and a grade-12 class had been asked to self-isolate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassidy Randall
title: Ghost Ships
description: My sister was my other half until we tacked in different directions, making our own life choices.
content: “We’re jumping in here?” I ask my sister, as we rush to jam fins on our feet and sling snorkels over salty ponytails. Nervousness lodges in my throat as I consider the blue deep that goes on forever under the catamaran’s rolling hull.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Barry Meier
title: Which Nxivm Show Is Better? An Expert Investigates
description: The reporter who broke the story of the cult for The New York Times thought he was done with Nxivm. But he couldn’t resist seeing how “The Vow” and “Seduced” compared with his own experiences.
content: It was the comedian Judd Apatow who convinced me to invest a little too much of my time in the two recent documentaries about the sex cult Nxivm.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Plagued by delays, the American Dream mall finally opened in October. Then the pandemic hit.
description: It took more than 15 years for the American Dream mall to begin opening its doors in October 2019. The massive shopping and entertainment complex in East Rutherford, N.J., faced numerous delays as it cycled through developers and billions of dollars in funding.
content: It took more than 15 years for the American Dream mall to begin opening its doors in October 2019. The massive shopping and entertainment complex in East Rutherford, N.J., faced numerous delays as it cycled through developers and billions of dollars in funding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Jailed, Exiled and Silenced: Smothering East Africa’s Political Opposition
description: In several countries, entrenched leaders are taking advantage of coronavirus restrictions and a world distracted by the pandemic to clamp down hard on prominent political opponents.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — Since the presidential campaign kicked off in Uganda in early November, the most prominent opposition candidate, Bobi Wine, has been tear-gassed, arrested and beaten by the police, held in solitary confinement, and charged in court for holding campaign events in violation of coronavirus restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: The military’s role in a vaccine will be strictly behind the scenes, despite Trump’s claims.
description: When President Trump talks about efforts to deliver the coronavirus vaccine to millions of Americans eager to return to their normal lives, he often says he is “counting on the military” to get it done.
content: When President Trump talks about efforts to deliver the coronavirus vaccine to millions of Americans eager to return to their normal lives, he often says he is “counting on the military” to get it done.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Addario
title: Pregnant, Exhausted and Turned Back at the Border
description: The Trump administration’s restrictive immigration policies have not deterred pregnant women from seeking to enter the United States.
content: MATAMOROS, Mexico — Griselda was 38 weeks pregnant when she sneaked across the Rio Grande into the United States late one night last year. She started having contractions in a Border Patrol facility in McAllen, Texas, and was taken to a hospital where the medical staff gave her an injection to calm her pain and stop her from going into early labor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliana Kim
title: ‘Remain home and stay on the good list,’ say N.Y.C. SantaCon organizers.
description: New York City streets will officially be devoid of throngs of the jolliest — and perhaps most inebriated — St. Nicks this year. SantaCon, the daylong bar-crawling event that some people love, and many love to hate, has been canceled.
content: New York City streets will officially be devoid of throngs of the jolliest — and perhaps most inebriated — St. Nicks this year. SantaCon, the daylong bar-crawling event that some people love, and many love to hate, has been canceled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: How the Singer Patty Smyth Spends Her Sundays
description: The frontwoman of the 1980s band Scandal talks about promoting her solo album during a pandemic and her 23-year marriage to the tennis star John McEnroe.
content: Patty Smyth, the husky-voiced lead singer of Scandal, known for its 1984 love anthem, “The Warrior,” would not have put out her first solo album of original songs in 28 years had she known the pandemic would last this long. “People ask me,” she said, “and I’m like, you think this is what I chose?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine May
title: Wasn’t It Winter Just Yesterday?
description: The pandemic has unmoored us from time.
content: In September, I bought a visual timer for Bert, my 8-year-old son. It’s just like a clock, but instead of hands, it has a red plastic film that turns the hour into a kind of pie chart. Set it to 15 minutes, and it silently counts down. Three beeps when it’s done.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: E.P.A.’s Final Deregulatory Rush Runs Into Open Staff Resistance
description: As President Trump's Environmental Protection Agency rushes to complete its regulatory rollbacks, agency staff, emboldened by the Biden victory, moves to stand in the way.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s Environmental Protection Agency was rushing to complete one of its last regulatory priorities, aiming to obstruct the creation of air- and water-pollution controls far into the future, when a senior career scientist moved to hobble it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: I’ve Been Wearing Masks for Months and I Still Have Questions
description: Should masks be stored with the underwear or with the socks?
content: Recently, at a funeral, I got to thinking about the lesser challenges of the mask. Not the should-you-or-shouldn’t-you, which is settled science at this point, but the specific problem of how to cry with a mask on. This was especially pressing for me because, as an incorrigible weeper — it doesn’t matter if I’m a third friend twice removed — I was streaming tears before the service had begun. But the mask posed a new challenge: How to blow my nose discreetly and with enough frequency that I didn’t wind up with a big wet splotch in the middle, surely a repellent look during a raging pandemic? How to lift my mask to do the requisite wiping without someone looking askance?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Krauss
title: Gift Books for Children (That Adults Will Also Love)
description: Upside-down fairy tales, a neon periodic table, the art of Ramona Quimby and more.
content: TELEPHONE TALESBy Gianni Rodari Illustrated by Valerio VidaliTranslated by Antony Shugaar 212 pp. Enchanted Lion. $27.95. (Ages 8 to 12)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Politi and Manuela Andreoni
title: Argentina, and Latin America, Mourn Maradona as a Man of the People
description: Known for siding with leftist leaders and causes, the soccer legend’s life, and his politics, never strayed far from his impoverished roots, and his fans loved him for it.
content: BUENOS AIRES — The tens of thousands of fans who gathered on Thursday to pay their last respects to Diego Armando Maradona, Argentina’s soccer legend, as he lay in state in the presidential palace were often the first to say their idol was a genius with the ball, but he wasn’t perfect. He never pretended to be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Bengal
title: Even From the Desert, Danny Lyon Still Speaks to the Streets
description: The indefatigable photographer on the struggles of getting his new film to the next generation of activists.
content: BERNALILLO, N.M. — On Nov. 4, the morning after the election, hope and uncertainty mingled in the air outside the adobe house of the photographer and filmmaker Danny Lyon. Wind ruffled the branches of the golden cottonwoods he planted when he built the place in the early 1970s; it was sunny out. “I’m an eternal optimist,” he said. Mr. Lyon wore a Stetson hat, a blue button-down shirt, a face mask; green suspenders hitched up his jeans. In some parts of the country he has occasionally been mistaken for his University of Chicago classmate Bernie Sanders, for whom he stumped in 2019. “I just wave back at everybody,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: Royal Watchers Wonder: Do the Royals Watch ‘The Crown’?
description: A lack of hard facts has not prevented plenty of speculation as to whether Queen Elizabeth and the other members of the royal family ever watch their fictionalized selves.
content: If there were a TV show that portrayed your family as a clueless bunch of snobs and philanderers who helped drive a mentally fragile young princess to despair, would you watch it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Bruenig
title: Forgive Us Our Debts
description: Churches are doing what politicians have been unable to do, rescuing Americans from crushing medical bills.
content: Vanessa Matos couldn’t believe what she was reading. “I was like, OK, this is a scam,” she recalled of the letter she received in February. Her husband, she said, had the same reaction: “Yeah, this isn’t real.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: HBO Documentary Has Competition. These Women Don’t Seem Worried.
description: These days everybody wants a piece of the nonfiction game. HBO’s documentary heads, Nancy Abraham and Lisa Heller, talked about how they’re navigating the evolving landscape.
content: With documentaries a central part of the national conversation, it’s easy to forget that not only were they once relatively hard to find but they also had a damning reputation as being good for you — the kiss of death in entertainment terms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: The Best of Late Night This Week
description: The late-night hosts took the holiday off, and all seemed thankful earlier in the week that there were still plenty of White House antics to discuss.
content: The late-night hosts took the holiday off, and all seemed thankful earlier in the week that there were still plenty of White House antics to discuss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta and Nadja Popovich
title: Wildfire Smoke Is Poisoning California’s Kids. Some Pay a Higher Price.
description: Fires are making the state’s air more dangerous. How much that hurts depends largely on where you live and how much money your family has.
content: Fires are making the state’s air more dangerous. How much that hurts depends largely on where you live and how much money your family has.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Toby Bilanow
title: Weekly Health Quiz: Better Masks, a Sleep Benefit and Another Coronavirus Vaccine
description: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
content: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra McGuffie
title: The Weekender
description: “Are you OK?” asks Meghan, Duchess of Sussex. The chameleon of leftovers. The legacy of Mayor David Dinkins. And more.
content: “Are you OK?” asks Meghan, Duchess of Sussex. The chameleon of leftovers. The legacy of Mayor David Dinkins. And more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: In Argentina, Thousands Wait in Line for Maradona’s Wake
description: Tens of thousands of people stood in line on Thursday, including Vice President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner of Argentina, to bid farewell to the soccer legend Diego Armando Maradona, as his body lay in repose in the presidential palace.
content: Tens of thousands of people stood in line on Thursday, including Vice President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner of Argentina, to bid farewell to the soccer legend Diego Armando Maradona, as his body lay in repose in the presidential palace.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Is There a Lockstep Mentality on the Left?
description: Readers react to a column by Bret Stephens arguing that “groupthink” is blinding progressives.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Looking for Better Ways of Running Elections
description: A reader endorses a bill that includes automatic voter registration. Another says we should keep our electoral system decentralized. Also: A broader view of education; the flag isn’t partisan.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
